The school auditorium has 5 rows of seats. There are 20 seats in each row. One-third of the seats were occupied by the teachers. One-fourth of the remaining seats were occupied by the staff and the rest were occupied by the students. How many students were there in the school auditorium?

Total number of seats = 5 x 20 = 100Number of seats occupied by the teachers = 100/3 = 33.33 (rounded to 33)Number of remaining seats = 100 - 33 = 67Number of seats occupied by the staff = 67/4 = 16.75 (rounded to 17)Number of seats occupied by the students = 67 - 17 = 50

The school gymnasium has 6 rows of seats. There are 25 seats in each row. One-fifth of the seats were occupied by the coaches. One-sixth of the remaining seats were occupied by the parents and the rest were occupied by the students. How many students were there in the school gymnasium?

Total number of seats = 6 x 25 = 150Number of seats occupied by the coaches = 150/5 = 30Number of remaining seats = 150 - 30 = 120Number of seats occupied by the parents = 120/6 = 20Number of seats occupied by the students = 120 - 20 = 100

The school cafeteria has 8 rows of seats. There are 30 seats in each row. One-sixth of the seats were occupied by the faculty. One-eighth of the remaining seats were occupied by the staff and the rest were occupied by the students. How many students were there in the school cafeteria?

Total number of seats = 8 x 30 = 240Number of seats occupied by the faculty = 240/6 = 40Number of remaining seats = 240 - 40 = 200Number of seats occupied by the staff = 200/8 = 25Number of seats occupied by the students = 200 - 25 = 175

The school library has 10 rows of seats. There are 35 seats in each row. One-eighth of the seats were occupied by the librarians. One-tenth of the remaining seats were occupied by the volunteers and the rest were occupied by the students. How many students were there in the school library?

Total number of seats = 10 x 35 = 350Number of seats occupied by the librarians = 350/8 = 43.75 (rounded to 44)Number of remaining seats = 350 - 44 = 306Number of seats occupied by the volunteers = 306/10 = 30.6 (rounded to 31)Number of seats occupied by the students = 306 - 31 = 275

The school theater has 12 rows of seats. There are 40 seats in each row. One-tenth of the seats were occupied by the stage crew. One-fifth of the remaining seats were occupied by the ushers and the rest were occupied by the audience. How many audience members were there in the school theater?

Total number of seats = 12 x 40 = 480Number of seats occupied by the stage crew = 480/10 = 48Number of remaining seats = 480 - 48 = 432Number of seats occupied by the ushers = 432/5 = 86.4 (rounded to 86)Number of seats occupied by the audience = 432 - 86 = 346
A school has 8 classrooms, and each classroom has 25 students. If 10 students are absent, how many students are present in the school?

Total number of students in the school = Number of classrooms x Number of students in each classroom= 8 x 25= 200Number of absent students = 10Number of present students = Total number of students - Number of absent students= 200 - 10= 190
A store has 12 shelves, and each shelf has 15 items. If 20 items are sold, how many items are left on the shelves?

Total number of items on the shelves = Number of shelves x Number of items on each shelf= 12 x 15= 180Number of sold items = 20Number of items left on the shelves = Total number of items - Number of sold items= 180 - 20= 160
A company has 5 departments, and each department has 10 employees. If 3 employees from each department are on vacation, how many employees are working in the company?

Total number of employees in the company = Number of departments x Number of employees in each department= 5 x 10= 50Number of employees on vacation = Number of departments x Number of employees on vacation in each department= 5 x 3= 15Number of employees working in the company = Total number of employees - Number of employees on vacation= 50 - 15= 35
A restaurant has 15 tables, and each table can seat 4 people. If 10 tables are occupied, how many people can be seated in the restaurant?

Total number of people that can be seated in the restaurant = Number of tables x Number of people that can be seated on each table= 15 x 4= 60Number of occupied tables = 10Number of unoccupied tables = Total number of tables - Number of occupied tables= 15 - 10= 5Number of people that can be seated in the unoccupied tables = Number of unoccupied tables x Number of people that can be seated on each table= 5 x 4= 20Total number of people that can be seated in the restaurant = Number of people that can be seated in the occupied tables + Number of people that can be seated in the unoccupied tables= 10 x 4 + 20= 60
A factory produces 500 units of a product per day. If 50 units are defective, what is the percentage of non-defective units produced?

Total number of units produced per day = 500Number of defective units = 50Number of non-defective units = Total number of units produced - Number of defective units= 500 - 50= 450Percentage of non-defective units produced = (Number of non-defective units / Total number of units produced) x 100%= (450 / 500) x 100%= 90%
A car can run for 200,000 miles before it needs a new engine. A car has already run for 78,000 miles. How many more miles can the car run before it needs a new engine?

To find out how many more miles the car can run before it needs a new engine, we need to subtract the number of miles it has already run from the total number of miles it can run. So, 200,000 - 78,000 = 122,000.

Samantha needs to go to physical therapy. She went to physical therapy for 8 weeks. Each week she went three times for 1 hour at a time. If the sessions cost $150 per hour how much did the physical therapy cost?

Samantha has a 24 pack of crayons. She uses 2 crayons for every 3 pages she colors in her coloring book. She colors 5 pages before school, 4 pages during recess, and 6 pages after school. She also gives 4 crayons to her friend during lunch. How many crayons does Samantha have left?
Samantha colors a total of 5 + 4 + 6 = 15 pages. She uses 2 crayons for every 3 pages, so she uses 2/3 * 15 = 10 crayons. She gives 4 crayons to her friend, so she has 24 - 10 - 4 = 10 crayons left.
Tom has a bag of 50 marbles. He gives 3 marbles to his friend and then loses 5 marbles while playing. He then divides the remaining marbles equally into 4 bags. How many marbles are in each bag?

Tom starts with 50 marbles. He gives 3 away, so he has 50 - 3 = 47 marbles. He loses 5 marbles, so he has 47 - 5 = 42 marbles left. He divides these equally into 4 bags, so each bag has 42/4 = 10.5 marbles. Since he can't have half a marble, he rounds down to get 10 marbles in each bag.

Emily uses 4 buttons for every 2 inches of fabric, so she uses 4/2 = 2 buttons for every inch of fabric. She sews a total of 12 + 18 = 30 inches of fabric, so she uses 2 * 30 = 60 buttons. She gives 10 buttons to her sister, so she has 80 - 60 - 10 = 10 buttons left.

John uses 2 pencils for every 5 math problems, so he uses 2/5 * 15 = 6 pencils before lunch and 2/5 * 20 = 8 pencils after lunch. He gives 6 pencils to his friend, so he has 36 - 6 - 6 - 8 = 16 pencils left.

Lily eats a total of 3 + 4 = 7 candies. She gives 10 candies to her brother, so she has 60 - 7 - 10 = 43 candies left.

A store has 12 boxes of chocolates, each box has 24 chocolates. If only 3/5 of the chocolates are dark chocolate, how many dark chocolates are there in the store?
Total number of chocolates = 12 x 24 = 288Number of dark chocolates = 288 x 3/5 = 172.8 ≈ 173
A classroom has 30 students, but only 4/7 of them are present today. How many students are present in the classroom?
Number of students present = 30 x 4/7 = 17.14 ≈ 17
A company has 50 employees, but only 3/5 of them have completed the training program. How many employees have completed the training program?
Number of employees who completed the training program = 50 x 3/5 = 30
If John has an internet connection speed of 50kb per second, what is his internet connection speed in Mb per hour?

First, we need to convert the internet connection speed from kb per second to Mb per second. 1 Mb is equal to 1000 kb. So, John's internet connection speed in Mb per second is 50/1000 = 0.05 Mb per second. To find his internet connection speed in Mb per hour, we need to multiply his internet connection speed in Mb per second by the number of seconds in an hour, which is 3600. So, John's internet connection speed in Mb per hour is 0.05 x 3600 = 180 Mb per hour.

On a particular week, a tow truck pulled eight cars for each of the first four days and then three fewer cars on each of the remaining days of the week. Calculate the total number of cars it towed that week.

The number of cars towed on the first four days is 8 x 4 = 32.The number of cars towed on the remaining three days is (8 - 3) x 3 = 15.Therefore, the total number of cars towed that week is 32 + 15 = 47.

On a particular week, a tow truck pulled twelve cars for each of the first two days and then five fewer cars on each of the remaining days of the week. Calculate the total number of cars it towed that week.

The number of cars towed on the first two days is 12 x 2 = 24.The number of cars towed on the remaining five days is (12 - 5) x 5 = 35.Therefore, the total number of cars towed that week is 24 + 35 = 59.

On a particular week, a tow truck pulled six cars for each of the first five days and then two fewer cars on each of the remaining days of the week. Calculate the total number of cars it towed that week.
The number of cars towed on the first five days is 6 x 5 = 30.The number of cars towed on the remaining two days is (6 - 2) x 2 = 8.Therefore, the total number of cars towed that week is 30 + 8 = 38.

On a particular week, a tow truck pulled fifteen cars for each of the first three days and then six fewer cars on each of the remaining days of the week. Calculate the total number of cars it towed that week.

The number of cars towed on the first three days is 15 x 3 = 45.The number of cars towed on the remaining four days is (15 - 6) x 4 = 36.Therefore, the total number of cars towed that week is 45 + 36 = 81.

On a particular week, a tow truck pulled nine cars for each of the first four days and then four fewer cars on each of the remaining days of the week. Calculate the total number of cars it towed that week.

The number of cars towed on the first four days is 9 x 4 = 36.The number of cars towed on the remaining three days is (9 - 4) x 3 = 15.Therefore, the total number of cars towed that week is 36 + 15 = 51.
Samantha wants to buy a toy that costs $25. She has saved $10 so far and plans to save $5 each week. How many weeks will it take her to save enough money to buy the toy?

To find out how many weeks it will take Samantha to save enough money to buy the toy, we need to subtract the amount she has saved from the cost of the toy and then divide the result by the amount she saves each week. So, $25 - $10 = $15. Then, $15 ÷ $5 = 3. Therefore, it will take Samantha 3 weeks to save enough money to buy the toy.
John wants to run a 5K race. He can run 1 kilometer in 6 minutes. How long will it take him to finish the race?

To find out how long it will take John to finish the race, we need to multiply the distance of the race (5 kilometers) by the time it takes him to run 1 kilometer (6 minutes). So, 5 km x 6 min/km = 30 minutes. Therefore, it will take John 30 minutes to finish the race.
A recipe calls for 2 cups of flour to make 12 cookies. If you want to make 24 cookies, how many cups of flour do you need?

To find out how many cups of flour you need to make 24 cookies, we need to use a proportion. If 2 cups of flour make 12 cookies, then 1 cup of flour makes 6 cookies. So, to make 24 cookies, we need 4 cups of flour (24 cookies ÷ 6 cookies/cup = 4 cups).
A car travels 240 miles in 4 hours. What is the average speed of the car in miles per hour?

To find out the average speed of the car in miles per hour, we need to divide the distance traveled by the time it took to travel that distance. So, 240 miles ÷ 4 hours = 60 miles per hour. Therefore, the average speed of the car is 60 miles per hour.
A store is having a sale where all items are 20% off. If a shirt originally costs $25, how much will it cost during the sale?

To find out how much the shirt will cost during the sale, we need to multiply the original price of the shirt by the percentage discount (20%) and then subtract that amount from the original price. So, 20% of $25 = $5. Then, $25 - $5 = $20. Therefore, the shirt will cost $20 during the sale.
John buys a house for $200,000 and sells it for $250,000. He pays a 5% commission to the real estate agent. How much profit did he make?
Samantha invests $10,000 in a stock that increases in value by 20%. She sells the stock and pays a 2% commission to her broker. How much profit did she make?
Samantha's stock is now worth $12,000 (20% increase from $10,000). She pays a commission of $240 (2% of $12,000) to her broker. Her profit is $12,000 - $10,000 - $240 = $1,760.
David buys a car for $15,000 and sells it for $18,000. He pays a 10% commission to the dealership. How much profit did he make?
Emily buys a painting for $5,000 and sells it for $7,000. She pays a 15% commission to the art dealer. How much profit did she make?
Emily sold the painting for $7,000 - $1,050 (15% of $7,000) = $5,950. Her profit is $5,950 - $5,000 = $950.

In a school of 500 students, 40% of the students are in the science club. Of these students, 70% are girls. How many boys are in the science club?

First, we find the number of students in the science club by multiplying the total number of students by the percentage in the science club: 500 x 0.4 = 200. Then, we find the percentage of boys in the science club by subtracting the percentage of girls from 100%: 100% - 70% = 30%. Finally, we find the number of boys in the science club by multiplying the total number of students in the science club by the percentage of boys: 200 x 0.3 = 60.
A company has 300 employees, and 20% of them work in the marketing department. Of these employees, 40% are managers. How many non-managerial employees are in the marketing department?

First, we find the number of employees in the marketing department by multiplying the total number of employees by the percentage in the marketing department: 300 x 0.2 = 60. Finally, we find the number of non-managerial employees in the marketing department by multiplying the total number of employees in the marketing department by the percentage of non-managerial employees: 60 x 0.6 = 36.
A store has 500 items in stock, and 30% of them are shirts. Of these shirts, 25% are red. How many red shirts are in stock?

First, we find the number of shirts in stock by multiplying the total number of items by the percentage of shirts: 500 x 0.3 = 150. A restaurant has 50 tables, and 40% of them are occupied. Of these occupied tables, 60% have more than 4 people. How many tables have 4 or fewer people?

First, we find the number of occupied tables by multiplying the total number of tables by the percentage of occupied tables: 50 x 0.4 = 20. Finally, we find the number of tables with 4 or fewer people by multiplying the total number of occupied tables by the percentage of tables with 4 or fewer people: 20 x 0.4 = 8.

Finally, we find the number of employees with a college degree who have been with the company for more than 5 years by multiplying the total number of employees with a college degree by the percentage with more than 5 years: 25 x 0.2 = 5.

In a clothing store, the price of a shirt is 3/4 times as much as the price of a pair of pants. The cost of a jacket is $50 more than the price of a shirt. If a pair of pants costs $80, find the total price for all three items.

- Let's start by finding the price of a shirt. Since a shirt costs 3/4 times as much as a pair of pants, we can multiply $80 by 3/4 to get $60.- Next, we need to find the price of a jacket. We know that a jacket costs $50 more than a shirt, so we can add $50 to $60 to get $110.- Finally, we can add up the prices of all three items: $80 + $60 + $110 = $250.

In a grocery store, the price of a pound of beef is 5/6 times as much as the price of a pound of chicken. The cost of a pound of pork is $2 less than the price of beef. If a pound of chicken costs $4, find the total price for all three meats.

- Let's start by finding the price of a pound of beef. In a bookstore, the price of a hardcover book is 3/8 times as much as the price of a paperback book. The cost of an audiobook is $5 more than the price of a hardcover book. If a paperback book costs $10, find the total price for all three books.

Samantha went to the store and bought some apples and oranges. She bought 5 more oranges than apples, and a total of 18 fruits. How many apples did Samantha buy?

Let's assume that Samantha bought x apples. Then, she bought x+5 oranges. The total number of fruits she bought is x + (x+5) = 2x + 5. We know that the total number of fruits is 18, so we can set up the equation 2x + 5 = 18. Solving for x, we get x = 6. Therefore, Samantha bought 6 apples.

John is 60 miles ahead of Sarah, driving 50 miles per hour. Sarah is driving 65 miles per hour. How long will it take Sarah to catch up with John?

Let's assume that it takes Sarah t hours to catch up with John. In that time, John would have driven 50t miles and Sarah would have driven 65t miles. The distance between them would be 60 - 50t. To catch up, Sarah needs to cover this distance, so we can set up the equation: 65t = 60 - 50t. Solving for t, we get t = 2 hours.

Samantha has 5 more apples than John and John has 3 less than Michael. If Michael has 10 apples, how many apples does Samantha have?

Samantha, Alex, and Tyler went on a hike. Tyler hiked 6 miles. Samantha hiked 3 times what Tyler hiked and 2 miles farther than Alex. How many miles did Alex hike?

Let's start by setting up an equation for Samantha's distance: Samantha = 3 * Tyler + 2 + Alex. We know Tyler hiked 6 miles, so we can substitute that in: Samantha = 3 * 6 + 2 + Alex. In a grocery store, six apples cost $7.80, and four oranges cost $4.40. How much will Clyde pay for 8 apples and 6 oranges?

To find the cost of 8 apples, we can use proportion: 4 apples cost $5.20, so 8 apples cost 2 times as much, which is $10.40. Similarly, 3 oranges cost $3.30, so 6 oranges cost 2 times as much, which is $6.60. Therefore, Clyde will pay $10.40 + $6.60 = $17.00 for 8 apples and 6 oranges.
In a grocery store, five bananas cost $2.50, and two pineapples cost $6.00. How much will Jane pay for 3 bananas and 4 pineapples?

John is 35 years old. His wife is 3 years younger than him. Their daughter is currently half as old as her mom and their daughter's husband is 5 years older than her. How old is John's daughter's husband?

On Wednesday, John bought 15 apples at $2 each. At the till, he got a 20% discount because he had a coupon. The next day, the price of apples increased to $3 per fruit, but the store also offered a 15% discount on the total cost. If Jane took advantage of the discount and bought 15 apples, what is the difference between the final prices paid for the apples on the two days?
John paid $24 for the apples on Tuesday ($20 x 20% discount = $16). On Wednesday, Jane paid $38.25 for the apples ($45 - 15% discount = $38.25). The difference between the two prices is $14.25.

On Monday, Tom bought 30 oranges at $1.50 each. At the till, he got a 10% discount because he had a coupon. The next day, the price of oranges increased to $2 per fruit, but the store also offered a 20% discount on the total cost. If Sarah took advantage of the discount and bought 30 oranges, what is the difference between the final prices paid for the oranges on the two days?
Tom paid $40.50 for the oranges on Monday ($45 - 10% discount = $40.50). On Tuesday, Sarah paid $48 for the oranges ($60 - 20% discount = $48). The difference between the two prices is $7.50.

On Thursday, Mark bought 25 lemons at $0.75 each. At the till, he got a 15% discount because he had a coupon. The next day, the price of lemons increased to $1 per fruit, but the store also offered a 25% discount on the total cost. If Lisa took advantage of the discount and bought 25 lemons, what is the difference between the final prices paid for the lemons on the two days?
Mark paid $15.94 for the lemons on Thursday ($18.75 - 15% discount = $15.94). On Friday, Lisa paid $18.75 for the lemons ($25 - 25% discount = $18.75). The difference between the two prices is $2.81.

On Saturday, Rachel bought 12 grapefruits at $2.50 each. At the till, she got a 5% discount because she had a coupon. The next day, the price of grapefruits increased to $3 per fruit, but the store also offered a 30% discount on the total cost. Rachel paid $30 for the grapefruits on Saturday ($2.50 x 12 = $30 - 5% discount = $28.50). On Sunday, Mike paid $25.20 for the grapefruits ($36 - 30% discount = $25.20). The difference between the two prices is $3.30.

A store sells two types of shirts, blue and green. In a particular month, the store sold 120 blue shirts, which is 3/5 of the total number of green shirts sold. If each blue shirt costs $15 and each green shirt costs $20, what was the total revenue from shirt sales in that month?

Let's start by finding the total number of green shirts sold. Since 120 blue shirts is 3/5 of the total number of green shirts sold, we can set up the equation: 120 = 3/5 * G, where G is the total number of green shirts sold. Solving for G, we get G = 200. Therefore, the total number of shirts sold is 120 + 200 = 320. The revenue from blue shirts is 120 * $15 = $1800, and the revenue from green shirts is 200 * $20 = $4000. Therefore, the total revenue from shirt sales in that month is $5800.

A company sells two types of laptops, A and B. In a particular month, the company sold 150 laptops of type A, which is 2/5 of the total number of laptops sold. If each laptop of type A costs $800 and each laptop of type B costs $1200, what was the total revenue from laptop sales in that month?

Let's start by finding the total number of laptops sold. Since 150 laptops of type A is 2/5 of the total number of laptops sold, we can set up the equation: 150 = 2/5 * L, where L is the total number of laptops sold. Solving for L, we get L = 375. Therefore, the total number of laptops sold is 375. The revenue from type A laptops is 150 * $800 = $120000, and the revenue from type B laptops is (375-150) * $1200 = $270000. Therefore, the total revenue from laptop sales in that month is $390000.

A restaurant sells two types of pizzas, Margherita and Pepperoni. In a particular month, the restaurant sold 200 Margherita pizzas, which is 3/5 of the total number of pizzas sold. If each Margherita pizza costs $10 and each Pepperoni pizza costs $12, what was the total revenue from pizza sales in that month?

Let's start by finding the total number of pizzas sold. Since 200 Margherita pizzas is 3/5 of the total number of pizzas sold, we can set up the equation: 200 = 3/5 * P, where P is the total number of pizzas sold. Solving for P, we get P = 333.33 (rounded to the nearest whole number). Therefore, the total number of pizzas sold is 333. The revenue from Margherita pizzas is 200 * $10 = $2000, and the revenue from Pepperoni pizzas is (333-200) * $12 = $1596. Therefore, the total revenue from pizza sales in that month is $3596.

A store sells two types of shoes, sneakers and sandals. In a particular month, the store sold 300 sneakers, which is 2/5 of the total number of shoes sold. If each sneaker costs $50 and each sandal costs $30, what was the total revenue from shoe sales in that month?

Let's start by finding the total number of shoes sold. Since 300 sneakers is 2/5 of the total number of shoes sold, we can set up the equation: 300 = 2/5 * S, where S is the total number of shoes sold. Solving for S, we get S = 750. Therefore, the total number of shoes sold is 750. The revenue from sneakers is 300 * $50 = $15000, and the revenue from sandals is (750-300) * $30 = $13500. Therefore, the total revenue from shoe sales in that month is $28500.

A company sells two types of phones, iPhone and Samsung. In a particular month, the company sold 400 iPhones, which is 3/5 of the total number of phones sold. If each iPhone costs $800 and each Samsung phone costs $600, what was the total revenue from phone sales in that month?

Let's start by finding the total number of phones sold. Since 400 iPhones is 3/5 of the total number of phones sold, we can set up the equation: 400 = 3/5 * P, where P is the total number of phones sold. Solving for P, we get P = 666.67 (rounded to the nearest whole number). Therefore, the total number of phones sold is 667. The revenue from iPhones is 400 * $800 = $320000, and the revenue from Samsung phones is (667-400) * $600 = $100200. Therefore, the total revenue from phone sales in that month is $420200.
James hires a horse-drawn carriage from 6 PM to 10 PM. He gets 1 hour free. The first paid hour is $20 and each hour after that is twice the cost. How much did he pay?

James hired the carriage for 4 hours, but he gets 1 hour free, so he only pays for 3 hours. The first hour costs $20, and each subsequent hour costs twice the previous hour. So the second hour costs $40, and the third hour costs $80. Therefore, James paid $20 + $40 + $80 = $140.
Sarah hires a car from 9 AM to 1 PM. She gets 30 minutes free. The first paid hour is $10 and each hour after that is $15. How much did she pay?

Sarah hired the car for 3.5 hours, but she gets 30 minutes free, so she only pays for 3 hours. The first hour costs $10, and each subsequent hour costs $15. So the second hour costs $15, and the third hour also costs $15. Therefore, Sarah paid $10 + $15 + $15 = $40.
John hires a bike from 2 PM to 6 PM. He gets 1 hour free. The first paid hour is $5 and each hour after that is $8. How much did he pay?

John hired the bike for 4 hours, but he gets 1 hour free, so he only pays for 3 hours. The first hour costs $5, and each subsequent hour costs $8. So the second hour costs $8, and the third hour also costs $8. Therefore, John paid $5 + $8 + $8 = $21.
Emily hires a boat from 11 AM to 3 PM. She gets 45 minutes free. The first paid hour is $25 and each hour after that is $30. How much did she pay?

Emily hired the boat for 3.25 hours, but she gets 45 minutes free, so she only pays for 2.75 hours. The first hour costs $25, and each subsequent hour costs $30. So the second hour costs $30, and the third hour also costs $30. Therefore, Emily paid $25 + $30 + $30 = $85.
Tom hires a limousine from 7 PM to 11 PM. He gets 1.5 hours free. The first paid hour is $50 and each hour after that is $60. How much did he pay?

Tom hired the limousine for 3.5 hours, but he gets 1.5 hours free, so he only pays for 2 hours. The first hour costs $50, and each subsequent hour costs $60. So the second hour also costs $60. Therefore, Tom paid $50 + $60 = $110.

John has realized he did not receive a full wage this week. His bank account, which held $150 at the start of the week, now holds $375. He has received no other money into his bank account this week. If his weekly wage should be $250, how many dollars were withheld from John’s wage?
John's bank account increased by $375 - $150 = $225 this week. This means he was paid $225 instead of his expected $250. Therefore, $250 - $225 = $25 was withheld from John's wage.

Emily's bank account increased by $525 - $300 = $225 this week. This means she was paid $225 instead of her expected $400. Therefore, $400 - $225 = $175 was withheld from Emily's wage.

Mike's bank account increased by $625 - $400 = $225 this week. This means he was paid $225 instead of his expected $500. Therefore, $500 - $225 = $275 was withheld from Mike's wage.

Lori needed 1 whole egg to make 2 deviled egg halves.  She anticipates that each of her guests will eat 3 deviled egg halves.  If she is inviting 16 guests to her party, how many dozens of eggs will she need?

Lori needs 1 egg to make 2 deviled egg halves, so she needs 2 eggs to make 4 deviled egg halves. Since each guest will eat 3 deviled egg halves, Lori needs 3/4 of an egg per guest. To find the total number of eggs needed, we multiply the number of guests by the amount of egg needed per guest: 16 guests * 3/4 egg per guest = 12 eggs. Since there are 12 eggs in a dozen, Lori needs 1 dozen eggs.
Samantha needs 2 cups of flour to make 12 cookies. If she wants to make 48 cookies, how many cups of flour will she need?

Samantha needs 2 cups of flour to make 12 cookies, so she needs 4 cups of flour to make 24 cookies (2 cups per 12 cookies). Since she wants to make 48 cookies, she needs twice as much flour as she needs for 24 cookies, which is 8 cups of flour.
John can paint a room in 4 hours. If he wants to paint 3 rooms, how many hours will it take him?
John can paint 1 room in 4 hours, so he can paint 3 rooms in 3 times as long, which is 12 hours (4 hours per room * 3 rooms).
A recipe calls for 1/2 cup of sugar to make 12 muffins. If you want to make 36 muffins, how many cups of sugar will you need?

The recipe calls for 1/2 cup of sugar to make 12 muffins, so you need 1.5 times as much sugar to make 36 muffins. To find out how much sugar you need, you can multiply the amount of sugar needed for 12 muffins by 1.5: 1/2 cup of sugar * 1.5 = 3/4 cup of sugar.
A car can travel 300 miles on 12 gallons of gas. If the car has a 20-gallon gas tank, how many miles can it travel on a full tank of gas?

The car can travel 300 miles on 12 gallons of gas, so it can travel 25 miles per gallon (300 miles / 12 gallons). If the gas tank holds 20 gallons, the car can travel 20 times as far on a full tank of gas: 25 miles per gallon * 20 gallons = 500 miles.
John has a 50-page book to read. He has already read 3/5 of the book. How many pages does he have left to read?

To find the number of pages John has left to read, we need to subtract the number of pages he has already read from the total number of pages in the book. Total number of pages in the book = 50Number of pages John has already read = 3/5 x 50 = 30Number of pages John has left to read = 50 - 30 = 20
A pizza has 8 slices. If 3/4 of the pizza is eaten, how many slices are left?

To find the number of slices left, we need to subtract the number of slices eaten from the total number of slices in the pizza.Total number of slices in the pizza = 8Number of slices eaten = 3/4 x 8 = 6Number of slices left = 8 - 6 = 2
A marathon is 26.2 miles long. If a runner has completed 2/3 of the marathon, how many miles does the runner have left to run?

To find the number of miles the runner has left to run, we need to subtract the number of miles the runner has already run from the total length of the marathon.Total length of the marathon = 26.2 milesNumber of miles the runner has already run = 2/3 x 26.2 = 17.47 miles (rounded to two decimal places)Number of miles the runner has left to run = 26.2 - 17.47 = 8.73 miles (rounded to two decimal places)
A car can travel 400 miles on a full tank of gas. If the car has already traveled 3/5 of the distance, how many miles does it have left to travel?

To find the number of miles the car has left to travel, we need to subtract the distance the car has already traveled from the total distance it can travel on a full tank of gas.Total distance the car can travel on a full tank of gas = 400 milesDistance the car has already traveled = 3/5 x 400 = 240 milesDistance the car has left to travel = 400 - 240 = 160 miles
A box contains 24 chocolates. If 5/6 of the chocolates are eaten, how many chocolates are left in the box?

To find the number of chocolates left in the box, we need to subtract the number of chocolates eaten from the total number of chocolates in the box.Total number of chocolates in the box = 24Number of chocolates eaten = 5/6 x 24 = 20Number of chocolates left in the box = 24 - 20 = 4
{If a student has to read a 300-page book in 45 days and plans to read 8 pages a day, how many days before the deadline will the student finish reading?}

The student has to read 300 pages in 45 days, so the student needs to read 300/45 = 6.67 pages per day. Since the student plans to read 8 pages a day, the student will finish reading the book in 300/8 = 37.5 days. Therefore, the student will finish reading the book 45 - 37.5 = 7.5 days before the deadline.
{If a student has to read a 150-page book in 25 days and plans to read 6 pages a day, how many days before the deadline will the student finish reading?}

The student has to read 150 pages in 25 days, so the student needs to read 150/25 = 6 pages per day. Since the student plans to read 6 pages a day, the student will finish reading the book in 150/6 = 25 days. Therefore, the student will finish reading the book on the deadline day.
{If a student has to read a 400-page book in 60 days and plans to read 12 pages a day, how many days before the deadline will the student finish reading?}

The student has to read 400 pages in 60 days, so the student needs to read 400/60 = 6.67 pages per day. Since the student plans to read 12 pages a day, the student will finish reading the book in 400/12 = 33.33 days. Therefore, the student will finish reading the book 60 - 33.33 = 26.67 days before the deadline.
{If a student has to read a 250-page book in 30 days and plans to read 9 pages a day, how many days before the deadline will the student finish reading?}

The student has to read 250 pages in 30 days, so the student needs to read 250/30 = 8.33 pages per day. Since the student plans to read 9 pages a day, the student will finish reading the book in 250/9 = 27.78 days. Therefore, the student will finish reading the book 30 - 27.78 = 2.22 days before the deadline.
{If a student has to read a 500-page book in 75 days and plans to read 7 pages a day, how many days before the deadline will the student finish reading?}

The student has to read 500 pages in 75 days, so the student needs to read 500/75 = 6.67 pages per day. Since the student plans to read 7 pages a day, the student will finish reading the book in 500/7 = 71.43 days. Therefore, the student will finish reading the book 75 - 71.43 = 3.57 days before the deadline.
Samantha buys a car. The car cost $25,000. She pays $200 a month for insurance. She also spends $100 a month on gas. How much did it cost her to get and maintain the car for the first year?

To find out how much Samantha spent on the car for the first year, we need to add up the cost of the car, insurance, and gas for 12 months. $25,000 (cost of car) + ($200/month x 12 months) (cost of insurance) + ($100/month x 12 months) (cost of gas) = $28,400

John buys a boat. The boat cost $30,000. He pays $300 a month to rent a slip to keep it in. He also spends $150 a month on maintenance. How much did it cost him to get and maintain the boat for the first year?

To find out how much John spent on the boat for the first year, we need to add up the cost of the boat, slip rental, and maintenance for 12 months. $30,000 (cost of boat) + ($300/month x 12 months) (cost of slip rental) + ($150/month x 12 months) (cost of maintenance) = $34,800

A bakery sells cakes and cookies. The ratio of the number of cakes to the number of cookies sold is 3:5. If the bakery sold 24 cakes, how many cookies did they sell?

Let's assume that the number of cakes sold is 3x and the number of cookies sold is 5x. We know that the bakery sold 24 cakes, so we can set up the equation 3x = 24. Solving for x, we get x = 8. Now we can find the number of cookies sold by multiplying 5x by 8: 5x * 8 = 40 * 8 = 320.
A car travels 120 miles in 2 hours. If it maintains the same speed, how far will it travel in 5 hours?

We can use the formula distance = rate * time. If the car travels 120 miles in 2 hours, its speed is 120/2 = 60 miles per hour. To find how far it will travel in 5 hours, we can multiply its speed by the time: 60 * 5 = 300.

A rectangular garden has a length of 12 meters and a width of 8 meters. If a path of uniform width is built around the garden, increasing the total area to 192 square meters, what is the width of the path?

The original area of the garden is 12 * 8 = 96 square meters. Let's assume that the width of the path is x meters. The length and width of the garden with the path are (12 + 2x) and (8 + 2x) meters, respectively. The total area is (12 + 2x) * (8 + 2x) = 192. Expanding and simplifying this equation, we get 4x^2 + 40x - 48 = 0. Solving for x using the quadratic formula, we get x = 2 or x = -6. Since the width of the path cannot be negative, the width of the path is 2 meters.
A company produces 5000 units of a product at a cost of $10 per unit. If the company sells each unit for $15, what is the profit?

The revenue from selling 5000 units at $15 per unit is 5000 * 15 = $75,000. The cost of producing 5000 units at $10 per unit is 5000 * 10 = $50,000. Therefore, the profit is $75,000 - $50,000 = $25,000.
A recipe calls for 2 cups of flour to make 12 cookies. How many cups of flour are needed to make 30 cookies?
We can set up a proportion to solve this problem: 2 cups / 12 cookies = x cups / 30 cookies. Cross-multiplying, we get 12x = 60, so x = 5. Therefore, 5 cups of flour are needed to make 30 cookies.

A pound of almonds costs $10 while a pound of walnuts costs $15. How much more does it cost for a mixture of 1/2 pound almonds and 1/3 pound walnuts than a mixture of 1/5 pound almonds and 1/3 pound walnuts?

The cost of 1/2 pound of almonds is (1/2) x $10 = $5. The cost of 1/3 pound of walnuts is (1/3) x $15 = $5. Therefore, the cost of the first mixture is $5 + $5 = $10. The cost of 1/5 pound of almonds is (1/5) x $10 = $2. The cost of 1/3 pound of walnuts is (1/3) x $15 = $5. Therefore, the cost of the second mixture is $2 + $5 = $7. The difference in cost is $10 - $7 = $3.

A pound of peanuts costs $8 while a pound of cashews costs $12. How much more does it cost for a mixture of 1/4 pound peanuts and 1/2 pound cashews than a mixture of 1/6 pound peanuts and 1/4 pound cashews?

The cost of 1/4 pound of peanuts is (1/4) x $8 = $2. The cost of 1/2 pound of cashews is (1/2) x $12 = $6. Therefore, the cost of the first mixture is $2 + $6 = $8. The cost of 1/6 pound of peanuts is (1/6) x $8 = $4/3. The cost of 1/4 pound of cashews is (1/4) x $12 = $3. Therefore, the cost of the second mixture is $4/3 + $3 = $13/3. The difference in cost is $13/3 - $8 = $1/3.

A pound of grapes costs $5 while a pound of cherries costs $8. How much more does it cost for a mixture of 1/3 pound grapes and 1/2 pound cherries than a mixture of 1/4 pound grapes and 1/3 pound cherries?

The cost of 1/3 pound of grapes is (1/3) x $5 = $5/3. The cost of 1/2 pound of cherries is (1/2) x $8 = $4. Therefore, the cost of the first mixture is $5/3 + $4 = $17/3. The cost of 1/4 pound of grapes is (1/4) x $5 = $5/4. The cost of 1/3 pound of cherries is (1/3) x $8 = $8/3. Therefore, the cost of the second mixture is $5/4 + $8/3 = $47/12. The difference in cost is $47/12 - $17/3 = $1/4.
A pound of lemons costs $3 while a pound of limes costs $4. How much more does it cost for a mixture of 1/2 pound lemons and 1/4 pound limes than a mixture of 1/3 pound lemons and 1/5 pound limes?

The cost of 1/2 pound of lemons is (1/2) x $3 = $3/2. The cost of 1/4 pound of limes is (1/4) x $4 = $1. Therefore, the cost of the first mixture is $3/2 + $1 = $5/2. The cost of 1/3 pound of lemons is (1/3) x $3 = $1. The cost of 1/5 pound of limes is (1/5) x $4 = $4/5. Therefore, the cost of the second mixture is $1 + $4/5 = $9/5. The difference in cost is $9/5 - $5/2 = $1/10.

A pound of strawberries costs $6 while a pound of blueberries costs $10. How much more does it cost for a mixture of 1/4 pound strawberries and 1/3 pound blueberries than a mixture of 1/5 pound strawberries and 1/4 pound blueberries?

The cost of 1/4 pound of strawberries is (1/4) x $6 = $3/2. The cost of 1/3 pound of blueberries is (1/3) x $10 = $10/3. Therefore, the cost of the first mixture is $3/2 + $10/3 = $11/3. The cost of 1/5 pound of strawberries is (1/5) x $6 = $6/5. The cost of 1/4 pound of blueberries is (1/4) x $10 = $5/2. Therefore, the cost of the second mixture is $6/5 + $5/2 = $17/5. The difference in cost is $17/5 - $11/3 = $4/15.
John has a collection of only cats and dogs. If the total number of animal legs is 32, and the total number of animal heads is 10, how many cats does John have?

Let's assume that John has x cats and y dogs. Since each cat has 4 legs and each dog has 4 legs, the total number of legs can be expressed as 4x + 4y = 32. Similarly, the total number of heads can be expressed as x + y = 10. We can solve these two equations simultaneously to get the value of x, which represents the number of cats. Solving for y, we get y = 10 - x. Substituting this value of y in the first equation, we get 4x + 4(10 - x) = 32. Simplifying this equation, we get x = 3.
Samantha has a collection of only rabbits and chickens. If the total number of animal legs is 48, and the total number of animal heads is 18, how many rabbits does Samantha have?

Let's assume that Samantha has x rabbits and y chickens. Since each rabbit has 4 legs and each chicken has 2 legs, the total number of legs can be expressed as 4x + 2y = 48. Similarly, the total number of heads can be expressed as x + y = 18. We can solve these two equations simultaneously to get the value of x, which represents the number of rabbits. Solving for y, we get y = 18 - x. Substituting this value of y in the first equation, we get 4x + 2(18 - x) = 48. Simplifying this equation, we get x = 6.
Tom has a collection of only cows and horses. If the total number of animal legs is 104, and the total number of animal heads is 30, how many cows does Tom have?

Let's assume that Tom has x cows and y horses. Since each cow has 4 legs and each horse has 4 legs, the total number of legs can be expressed as 4x + 4y = 104. Similarly, the total number of heads can be expressed as x + y = 30. We can solve these two equations simultaneously to get the value of x, which represents the number of cows. Solving for y, we get y = 30 - x. Substituting this value of y in the first equation, we get 4x + 4(30 - x) = 104. Simplifying this equation, we get x = 8.
Emily has a collection of only ducks and turkeys. If the total number of animal legs is 60, and the total number of animal heads is 20, how many ducks does Emily have?

Let's assume that Emily has x ducks and y turkeys. Since each duck has 2 legs and each turkey has 2 legs, the total number of legs can be expressed as 2x + 2y = 60. Similarly, the total number of heads can be expressed as x + y = 20. We can solve these two equations simultaneously to get the value of x, which represents the number of ducks. Solving for y, we get y = 20 - x. Substituting this value of y in the first equation, we get 2x + 2(20 - x) = 60. Simplifying this equation, we get x = 10.
David has a collection of only pigs and goats. If the total number of animal legs is 84, and the total number of animal heads is 24, how many pigs does David have?

Let's assume that David has x pigs and y goats. Since each pig has 4 legs and each goat has 4 legs, the total number of legs can be expressed as 4x + 4y = 84. Similarly, the total number of heads can be expressed as x + y = 24. We can solve these two equations simultaneously to get the value of x, which represents the number of pigs. Solving for y, we get y = 24 - x. Substituting this value of y in the first equation, we get 4x + 4(24 - x) = 84. Simplifying this equation, we get x = 6.

Samantha has 40 more dollars than her sister, and her sister has 3/5 times as much money as their brother. If their brother has $100, how much would each have if they decided to add together their money and share equally among them?

There are two sets of twins. One twin is 5 years older than the other twin. If their combined ages are 34, how old is one of the twins?

Let's call the age of the younger twin x. Then the age of the older twin is x+5. The combined age of the twins is x+(x+5)=2x+5. We know that 2x+5=34, so 2x=29 and x=14.5. Since we are looking for an integer answer, we can round up to 15. Therefore, one of the twins is 15 years old.

There are two sets of twins. One twin is 6 years older than the other twin. If their combined ages are 40, how old is one of the twins?

Let's call the age of the younger twin x. Then the age of the older twin is x+6. The combined age of the twins is x+(x+6)=2x+6. We know that 2x+6=40, so 2x=34 and x=17. Therefore, one of the twins is 17 years old.

Samantha has 30 minutes of math homework, 20 minutes of reading homework, and 10 minutes of science homework. If she has 2 hours before she has to go to soccer practice, how many minutes does Samantha have to finish her homework?

There is space for 20 pencils in the box. If there are 4 pencils missing from the box, how many pairs of pencils are in the box?

To find the number of pairs of pencils in the box, we need to first find the total number of pencils in the box. If a car can travel 60 miles in 2 hours, how many miles can it travel in 5 hours?

A rabbit can eat 12 carrots in 24 minutes. A turtle can eat the same number of carrots in 3/4 the amount of time the rabbit takes. Calculate the average time the two take to eat the carrots.

Let's start by finding the time it takes for the turtle to eat 12 carrots. The rabbit eats 12 carrots in 24 minutes, so the turtle eats 12 carrots in (3/4) * 24 = 18 minutes. Therefore, the number of students who like to either watch movies or play chess is 60 - 15 - 10 = 35. Let x be the number of students who like to play chess. Then, the number of students who like to watch movies is 2 times the number of students who prefer playing soccer, which is 2 * 10 = 20. Therefore, the number of students who like to play chess is 35 - 20 = 15.

A class of 80 students has various hobbies. 20 like to draw, 15 like to play volleyball, and the rest like to either play tennis or watch TV. If the number that likes to play tennis is three times the number that prefers watching TV, how many students like to play tennis?

The total number of students in the class is 80. The number of students who like to draw is 20, and the number of students who like to play volleyball is 15. Therefore, the number of students who like to either play tennis or watch TV is 80 - 20 - 15 = 45. Let x be the number of students who like to play tennis. Then, the number of students who like to watch TV is one-third of the number of students who prefer playing tennis, which is x/3. Therefore, the number of students who like to play tennis is 45 - x/3. We can solve for x by setting this expression equal to the number of students who like to play tennis, which is x. So, we have 45 - x/3 = x. Solving for x, we get x = 30.

A restaurant has 60 seats. On Monday, 20 people came for lunch and 30 people came for dinner. On Tuesday, 15 people came for lunch and 25 people came for dinner. If the restaurant is open for 2 days, how many people on average came to the restaurant each day?

To find the average number of people who came to the restaurant each day, we need to add up the total number of people who came on both days and divide by the number of days. Total number of people who came = 20 + 30 + 15 + 25 = 90. Number of days = 2. Average number of people who came each day = 90 / 2 = 45.

A family wants to compare the cost of two different grocery stores. The first store has a $5 fee for each item and the second store has a $3 fee for each item. If they buy 4 items from each store, how much will they be able to save if they choose the second store over the first?

The cost of buying 4 items from the first store is 4 x $5 = $20. The cost of buying 4 items from the second store is 4 x $3 = $12. Therefore, they will be able to save $20 - $12 = $8 if they choose the second store over the first.

A group of 3 friends went to the movies. The total cost of the tickets was $36. How much will each friend pay if they split the cost equally?

Samantha has 12 pencils. She gave 3 pencils to her friend and lost 2 pencils. How many pencils does Samantha have now?

Samantha has 10 hours to divide between studying, exercising, and watching TV on the weekend. If she spends 2 hours watching TV and 1/4 of the remaining time exercising, what percentage of her weekend does she spend studying?

At the local Pick Your Own fruit orchard, you could pick your own blueberries for $4.00 per pound, strawberries were $3.00 per pound and raspberries were $5.00 per pound. If Sarah picked 3 pounds of blueberries, 5 pounds of strawberries and 2 pounds of raspberries, how much did she spend on fruit?

To find out how much Sarah spent on fruit, we need to multiply the pounds of each fruit by its price per pound and then add the results. So, the total cost would be: (3 x $4.00) + (5 x $3.00) + (2 x $5.00) = $12.00 + $15.00 + $10.00 = $37.00

At the local farmer's market, you could buy tomatoes for $1.50 per pound, cucumbers were $0.75 per pound and bell peppers were $2.00 per pound. If John bought 4 pounds of tomatoes, 3 pounds of cucumbers and 2 pounds of bell peppers, how much did he spend on vegetables?

The Smith family drove and hiked 8 hours to their vacation spot. They drove an average of 60 miles per hour and hiked an average of 4 miles per hour less than half their speed when they drive. If it took them 2 hours to hike, how far was their vacation spot?

Let's start by finding the distance they drove. Since they drove for 8 hours at an average speed of 60 miles per hour, the distance they drove is 8 x 60 = 480 miles. Next, let's find their hiking speed. Half of their driving speed is 60/2 = 30 miles per hour. Subtracting 4 miles per hour from this gives us their hiking speed, which is 30 - 4 = 26 miles per hour. Since they hiked for 2 hours at an average speed of 26 miles per hour, the distance they hiked is 2 x 26 = 52 miles. Therefore, the total distance to their vacation spot is 480 + 52 = 532 miles.

Three friends ordered three pizzas for a total of 45 dollars. If one of the pizzas cost 15 dollars, how much did each of the other two pizzas cost if they cost the same amount?
Let x be the cost of each of the other two pizzas. Then we have the equation 15 + 2x = 45. Solving for x, we get x = 15. Therefore, each of the other two pizzas cost 15 dollars.

Let x be the cost of each of the other four burgers. Then we have the equation 7 + 4x = 35. Solving for x, we get x = 7. Therefore, each of the other four burgers cost 7 dollars.

Let x be the cost of each of the other four sandwiches. Then we have the equation 18 + 18 + 4x = 54. Solving for x, we get x = 3. Therefore, each of the other four sandwiches cost 3 dollars.

John can run 4 miles a day for 6 days; but on two other days, he runs twice the distance he does on usual days. How many miles does he run in a week?

John runs 4 miles a day for 6 days, so he runs 4 x 6 = 24 miles in those 6 days. On the two other days, he runs twice the distance he does on usual days, so he runs 4 x 2 = 8 miles on those days. Therefore, he runs a total of 24 + 8 = 32 miles in a week.
Samantha can swim 10 laps a day for 4 days; but on two other days, she swims three times the laps she does on usual days. How many laps does she swim in a week?

Samantha swims 10 laps a day for 4 days, so she swims 10 x 4 = 40 laps in those 4 days. On the two other days, she swims three times the laps she does on usual days, so she swims 10 x 3 = 30 laps on those days. Therefore, she swims a total of 40 + 30 = 70 laps in a week.
Tom can read 20 pages a day for 5 days; but on two other days, he reads half the pages he does on usual days. How many pages does he read in a week?

Tom reads 20 pages a day for 5 days, so he reads 20 x 5 = 100 pages in those 5 days. On the two other days, he reads half the pages he does on usual days, so he reads 20 / 2 = 10 pages on those days. Therefore, he reads a total of 100 + 10 + 10 = 120 pages in a week.

John's car fuel efficiency is 20 MPG. If the current price for regular gas is $2.5/gallon, how much money is John's car consuming per week if he only uses his car to go to work from Monday to Friday and the one-way distance between his home and office is 10 miles?

John's car consumes 10 miles * 2 = 20 miles per day. In a week, John's car consumes 20 miles * 5 = 100 miles. Therefore, John's car consumes 100 miles / 20 MPG = 5 gallons of gas per week. The total cost of gas per week is 5 gallons * $2.5/gallon = $12.5.

A farmer has 10 apple trees and each tree yields 50 apples. If he also has 15 orange trees and each tree yields 30 oranges, how many fruits can the farmer get from his trees?
The number of apples the farmer can get is 10 x 50 = 500. The number of oranges the farmer can get is 15 x 30 = 450. Therefore, the total number of fruits the farmer can get is 500 + 450 = 950.

The number of pages the company can print in one minute using the first 4 printers is 4 x 100 = 400. The number of pages the company can print in one minute using the other 2 printers is 2 x 150 = 300. Therefore, the total number of pages the company can print in one minute is 400 + 300 = 700.

Samantha needs to paint a room that is 12 feet long, 10 feet wide, and 8 feet tall. If one gallon of paint covers 350 square feet, how many gallons of paint does Samantha need to buy?

To find the total area of the walls and ceiling, we need to find the area of each wall and the ceiling and then add them together. The area of one wall is 12 feet x 8 feet = 96 square feet. Since there are four walls, the total area of the walls is 4 x 96 = 384 square feet. The area of the ceiling is 10 feet x 12 feet = 120 square feet. So the total area to be painted is 384 + 120 = 504 square feet. To find the number of gallons of paint needed, we divide the total area by the coverage of one gallon of paint: 504 / 350 = 1.44 gallons.
A recipe calls for 2 cups of flour to make 12 cookies. If you want to make 24 cookies, how many cups of flour do you need?

We can set up a proportion to solve the problem. If 2 cups of flour make 12 cookies, then 1 cup of flour makes 6 cookies. To make 24 cookies, we need 4 times as much flour, so we multiply 2 cups by 4 to get 8 cups of flour.

A train has 215 people traveling on it. At the first stop 63 people get off and 18 more people get on, and at the next stop another 42 people get off. How many people are on the train?

John earns $15 per hour for 7 hours of work each day. Should he need to work additional hours, he is paid a special hourly rate that is 125% of his regular hourly rate. Last Wednesday, he worked 10 hours. How much was he paid, in dollars, for his work that day?

A group of friends went to a restaurant and ordered 3 pizzas and 2 pasta dishes. If each pizza takes 30 minutes to cook and each pasta dish takes 20 minutes to cook, how long will they have to wait for their food?

To find the total time they have to wait, we need to add the time it takes to cook the pizzas and the pasta dishes. The pizzas will take 3 x 30 = 90 minutes to cook and the pasta dishes will take 2 x 20 = 40 minutes to cook. So, the total time they have to wait is 90 + 40 = 130 minutes.

A company has 5 employees who work 8 hours a day. If each employee takes a 30-minute lunch break, how many hours of work are completed in a day?

In a basketball game, John scored 32 points. Sarah scored 8 less than half as many as John. How many points did John and Sarah have in total?
Let's first find out how many points Sarah scored. Half of John's score is 32/2 = 16. So, Sarah scored 8 less than 16, which is 16-8 = 8. Therefore, John and Sarah scored a total of 32+8 = 40 points.

In a hockey game, Emily scored 9 goals. Jack scored 1 less than half as many as Emily. How many goals did Emily and Jack have in total?

Half of Emily's score is 9/2 = 4.5. So, Jack scored 1 less than 4.5, which is 4.5-1 = 3.5. Since we need an integer answer, we can round down 3.5 to 3. Therefore, Emily and Jack scored a total of 9+3 = 12 goals.

Samantha has 10 marbles. If she wants to buy enough marbles, such that the percentage of marbles is 20% of all of her toys, how many marbles should she buy?

To find out how many marbles Samantha needs to buy, we need to first figure out how many toys she has in total. Let's call that number "x". We know that the percentage of marbles is 20%, so we can set up the equation: 10/x = 0.2. To solve for x, we can cross-multiply: 10 = 0.2x. Dividing both sides by 0.2, we get x = 50. So Samantha has 50 toys in total. To find out how many marbles she needs to buy, we can set up another equation: (10 + y)/50 = 0.3, where "y" is the number of marbles she needs to buy. Solving for y, we get y = 5.

Two cars are driving on a highway. The first car is traveling at an average speed of 50 miles per hour when the second car passes it at an average speed of 80 miles per hour. If both cars continue on the highway at the same speed, how many miles will separate them after 3 hours?

The distance between the two cars when the second car passes the first car is the same as the distance they will be apart after 3 hours. Let's call this distance "d". The first car travels at a speed of 50 miles per hour for 3 hours, so it covers a distance of 50 x 3 = 150 miles. The second car travels at a speed of 80 miles per hour for 3 hours, so it covers a distance of 80 x 3 = 240 miles. Therefore, the distance between the two cars after 3 hours is d = 240 - 150 = 90 miles.

A book has 120 pages. If 30 pages are read on Monday and 40 pages are read on Tuesday, how many pages are left to be read?

A box has 24 chocolates. If 6 chocolates are eaten and 3 chocolates are given away, how many chocolates are left in the box?
Total number of chocolates in the box = 24Number of chocolates eaten = 6Number of chocolates given away = 3Number of chocolates left = 24 - 6 - 3 = 15

A group of 5 friends go to a water park.  Each friend can ride a water slide for 2 minutes with 1 ticket.  Two of the friends are significantly worse than the others and can only ride for half as long.  One of them is significantly better and can ride for 1.5 times as long.  They ride for 3 hours.  How many tickets are used?

Jack can play for 20 minutes with 1 quarter, so he can play for 60 minutes with 3 quarters.  His two friends who are worse can only play for half as long, so they can play for 10 minutes with 1 quarter or 30 minutes with 3 quarters.  His better friend can play for 1.5 times as long, so he can play for 30 minutes with 1 quarter or 90 minutes with 3 quarters.  They played for 4 hours, which is 240 minutes.  So, Jack and his two worse friends played for 60 + 60 + 30 = 150 minutes, while his better friend played for 90 minutes.  Therefore, they used 150/20 + 90/30 = 12.5 + 3 = 15.5 quarters, which is 3.875 dollars.

One of them is significantly better and can play for 1.5 times as long.  They play for 2 hours.  How much money is used?

Each friend can play one game with 2 dollars, so Jack and his two worse friends can play for half as long, which is 1 game for 1 dollar.  His better friend can play for 1.5 times as long, so he can play for 1.5 games with 3 dollars.  They played for 2 hours, which is 120 minutes.  So, Jack and his two worse friends played for 60 minutes, while his better friend played for 90 minutes.  Therefore, they used 60/30 + 90/20 = 2 + 4.5 = 6.5 dollars.

Each friend can play one game with 8 dollars, so Jack and his two worse friends can play for half as long, which is 1 game for 4 dollars. So, Jack and his two worse friends played for 180 minutes, while his better friend played for 270 minutes.  Therefore, they used 180/30 + 270/15 = 6 + 18 = 24 dollars.

Tanya makes a salt scrub from salt, oil, fragrance, citrus zest, and sugar. She makes enough to fill a 10-ounce jar each time. She uses the same amount of citrus zest as fragrance and the same amount of salt as sugar. She uses twice as much oil as salt and twice as much salt as zest. How many ounces of oil does she use?

Let's use the variable "x" to represent the amount of zest Tanya uses. Then, she uses x ounces of salt, 2x ounces of oil, x ounces of fragrance, and x ounces of sugar. We know that the total amount of ingredients adds up to 10 ounces, so we can write an equation: x + 2x + x + x + x = 10. Simplifying this equation, we get 6x = 10, which means x = 5/3. Therefore, Tanya uses 2x = 10/3 ounces of oil.

Sarah makes a smoothie from strawberries, bananas, yogurt, and honey. She uses twice as many strawberries as bananas and half as much yogurt as honey. She uses 2 cups of strawberries and 1/2 cup of yogurt. How many cups of honey does she use?

Let's use the variable "x" to represent the amount of bananas Sarah uses. Then, she uses 2x cups of strawberries, 1/2x cups of honey, and 1/4x cups of yogurt. We know that she uses 2 cups of strawberries and 1/2 cup of yogurt, so we can write two equations: 2x = 2 and 1/4x = 1/2. Solving for x in the second equation, we get x = 2. Therefore, Sarah uses 1/2x = 1 cup of honey.

Therefore, John uses x cups of cucumbers, which is 2 cups.

Mike makes a sandwich from bread, meat, cheese, and vegetables. He uses twice as much meat as cheese and half as much vegetables as meat. He uses 4 slices of bread and 1 cup of meat. How many slices of cheese does he use?

Let's use the variable "x" to represent the amount of cheese Mike uses. Then, he uses 2x cups of meat, x/2 cups of vegetables, and x cups of cheese. Since he uses the same amount of cheese on each slice of bread, he uses 1/8 cup of cheese per slice. Therefore, he uses 4 slices x 1/8 cup per slice = 1/2 cup of cheese in total.

Let x be the amount each student raised. The total amount raised by the students is 10x. So, we have the equation 10x + 20,000 = 60,000. Solving for x, we get x = 4,000.

On a particular day, John walked from his house to the park for 6 hours. The next day, he walked half as many hours to the grocery store. If each hour he walked 3 miles, how many miles did he walk in total?

John walked for 6 hours on the first day and half as many hours on the second day, which is 6/2 = 3 hours. Therefore, he walked for a total of 6 + 3 = 9 hours. Since he walked 3 miles per hour, he walked a total of 9 x 3 = 27 miles.
On Monday, Sarah ran from her house to the gym for 5 hours. The next day, she ran for half as many hours to the library. If each hour she ran 4 miles, how many miles did she run in total?

Sarah ran for 5 hours on Monday and half as many hours on the next day, which is 5/2 = 2.5 hours. Therefore, she ran for a total of 5 + 2.5 = 7.5 hours. Since she ran 4 miles per hour, she ran a total of 7.5 x 4 = 30 miles.

On a particular day, Tom walked from his house to the beach for 7 hours. The next day, he walked for half as many hours to the park. If each hour he walked 2 miles, how many miles did he walk in total?

Tom walked for 7 hours on the first day and half as many hours on the second day, which is 7/2 = 3.5 hours. Therefore, he walked for a total of 7 + 3.5 = 10.5 hours. Since he walked 2 miles per hour, he walked a total of 10.5 x 2 = 21 miles.
On Monday, Lisa ran from her house to the mall for 4 hours. The next day, she ran for half as many hours to the park. If each hour she ran 5 miles, how many miles did she run in total?

Lisa ran for 4 hours on Monday and half as many hours on the next day, which is 4/2 = 2 hours. Therefore, she ran for a total of 4 + 2 = 6 hours. Since she ran 5 miles per hour, she ran a total of 6 x 5 = 30 miles.

On a particular day, Mike walked from his house to the store for 9 hours. The next day, he walked for half as many hours to the park. If each hour he walked 3 miles, how many miles did he walk in total?

Mike walked for 9 hours on the first day and half as many hours on the second day, which is 9/2 = 4.5 hours. Therefore, he walked for a total of 9 + 4.5 = 13.5 hours. Since he walked 3 miles per hour, he walked a total of 13.5 x 3 = 40.5 miles.
Liam had 25 marbles in his collection. He added 10 more marbles to his collection and then gave away 1/5 of his marbles to his friend. How many marbles does Liam have now?

Liam had 25 marbles, and he added 10 more marbles to his collection, so he had 25 + 10 = 35 marbles. Liam gave away 1/5 of his marbles, which is 1/5 x 35 = 7 marbles. Therefore, Liam has 35 - 7 = 28 marbles now.
Sophie had 60 stickers in her collection. She gave away 1/3 of her stickers to her friend and then bought 20 more stickers. How many stickers does Sophie have now?
Sophie gave away 1/3 of her stickers, which is 1/3 x 60 = 20 stickers. Therefore, Sophie had 60 - 20 = 40 stickers left. Sophie bought 20 more stickers, so she has 40 + 20 = 60 stickers now.
Oliver had 80 toy cars in his collection. He sold 1/4 of his toy cars and then bought 30 more toy cars. How many toy cars does Oliver have now?
Oliver sold 1/4 of his toy cars, which is 1/4 x 80 = 20 toy cars. Therefore, Oliver had 80 - 20 = 60 toy cars left. Oliver bought 30 more toy cars, so he has 60 + 30 = 90 toy cars now.
Emma had 50 pencils in her pencil case. She lost 1/5 of her pencils and then found 10 more pencils. How many pencils does Emma have now?
Emma lost 1/5 of her pencils, which is 1/5 x 50 = 10 pencils. Therefore, Emma had 50 - 10 = 40 pencils left. Emma found 10 more pencils, so she has 40 + 10 = 50 pencils now.
Noah had 70 books in his bookshelf. He gave away 1/2 of his books to his friend and then bought 40 more books. How many books does Noah have now?
Noah gave away 1/2 of his books, which is 1/2 x 70 = 35 books. Therefore, Noah had 70 - 35 = 35 books left. Noah bought 40 more books, so he has 35 + 40 = 75 books now.
Samantha works 25 cycles of work a day. Each cycle has 4 different tasks and each task pays $1.50. How much does she make if she works a full 5 day week?

Samantha works 25 cycles a day, and each cycle has 4 tasks. So, she completes 25 x 4 = 100 tasks a day. Each task pays $1.50, so Samantha earns 100 x $1.50 = $150 a day. If she works a full 5 day week, she earns $150 x 5 = $750.
Tom works 40 cycles of work a day. Each cycle has 6 different tasks and each task pays $2.50. How much does he make if he works a full 6 day week?

Tom works 40 cycles a day, and each cycle has 6 tasks. So, he completes 40 x 6 = 240 tasks a day. Each task pays $2.50, so Tom earns 240 x $2.50 = $600 a day. If he works a full 6 day week, he earns $600 x 6 = $3600.
Emily works 20 cycles of work a day. Each cycle has 3 different tasks and each task pays $1.80. How much does she make if she works a full 4 day week?

Emily works 20 cycles a day, and each cycle has 3 tasks. So, she completes 20 x 3 = 60 tasks a day. Each task pays $1.80, so Emily earns 60 x $1.80 = $108 a day. If she works a full 4 day week, she earns $108 x 4 = $432.
David works 35 cycles of work a day. Each cycle has 5 different tasks and each task pays $2.00. How much does he make if he works a full 3 day week?

David works 35 cycles a day, and each cycle has 5 tasks. So, he completes 35 x 5 = 175 tasks a day. Each task pays $2.00, so David earns 175 x $2.00 = $350 a day. If he works a full 3 day week, he earns $350 x 3 = $1050.
Sarah works 30 cycles of work a day. Each cycle has 4 different tasks and each task pays $1.25. How much does she make if she works a full 2 day week?

Sarah works 30 cycles a day, and each cycle has 4 tasks. So, she completes 30 x 4 = 120 tasks a day. Each task pays $1.25, so Sarah earns 120 x $1.25 = $150 a day. If she works a full 2 day week, she earns $150 x 2 = $300.
In a race, John finished 5 seconds ahead of his friend, Sarah. John's time was 35 seconds. What was Sarah's time?

Let's use the fact that John finished 5 seconds ahead of Sarah to set up an equation. If Sarah's time is represented by x, then John's time is x + 5. We also know that John's time was 35 seconds, so we can set up the equation x + 5 = 35. Solving for x, we get x = 30.
A group of friends went out to eat and decided to split the bill evenly. If the total bill was $60 and there were 4 friends, how much did each person pay?
To find out how much each person paid, we can divide the total bill by the number of friends. So, 60 ÷ 4 = 15.
A store is having a sale where all items are 20% off. If a shirt originally costs $25, how much will it cost during the sale?
To find out the sale price, we can multiply the original price by the discount percentage (20% or 0.2) and subtract that from the original price. So, 25 - (0.2 x 25) = 20.
A recipe calls for 2 cups of flour to make 12 cookies. If you want to make 24 cookies, how much flour do you need?
We can set up a proportion to solve for the amount of flour needed. 2 cups ÷ 12 cookies = x cups ÷ 24 cookies. Solving for x, we get x = 4 cups.
A car travels 120 miles in 2 hours. What is the car's average speed in miles per hour?
To find the average speed, we can divide the distance traveled by the time it took to travel that distance. So, 120 miles ÷ 2 hours = 60 miles per hour.

Samantha bought 5 packages of cat food and 7 packages of dog food. Each package of cat food contained 9 tins, and each package of dog food contained 4 tins. How many more tins of dog food than cat food did Samantha buy?

To find the number of tins of cat food, we multiply the number of packages by the number of tins per package: 5 x 9 = 45. To find the number of tins of dog food, we multiply the number of packages by the number of tins per package: 7 x 4 = 28. To find the difference between the two, we subtract the number of tins of cat food from the number of tins of dog food: 28 - 45 = -17.

To find the number of tins of cat food, we multiply the number of packages by the number of tins per package: 3 x 7 = 21. To find the number of tins of cat food, we multiply the number of packages by the number of tins per package: 10 x 12 = 120. Samantha, Jack, and Emily have a total of 75 stickers. Samantha has 5 more stickers than Jack, and Emily has 3 times the amount of stickers that Jack has. How many stickers does Emily have?

Let's call the number of stickers Jack has "x". Then, Samantha has "x+5" stickers and Emily has "3x" stickers. We know that the total number of stickers is 75, so we can set up the equation: x + (x+5) + 3x = 75. Simplifying this equation, we get 5x + 5 = 75. Subtracting 5 from both sides, we get 5x = 70. Dividing both sides by 5, we get x = 14. Therefore, Emily has 3x = 3(14) = 42 stickers.

A group of friends went to a restaurant and ordered a total of 24 slices of pizza. John ordered 3 more slices than Sarah, and Sarah ordered twice as many slices as Alex. How many slices of pizza did Alex order?

Let's call the number of slices Alex ordered "x". Then, Sarah ordered "2x" slices and John ordered "2x+3" slices. We know that the total number of slices is 24, so we can set up the equation: x + 2x + 2x + 3 = 24. Simplifying this equation, we get 5x + 3 = 24. Subtracting 3 from both sides, we get 5x = 21. Dividing both sides by 5, we get x = 4.2. Since we can't have a fraction of a slice, we round down to the nearest whole number. Therefore, Alex ordered 4 slices of pizza.
A group of students have a total of 48 pencils. Tom has 5 more pencils than Jane, and Jane has twice as many pencils as Mark. How many pencils does Mark have?

Let's call the number of pencils Mark has "x". Then, Jane has "2x" pencils and Tom has "2x+5" pencils. We know that the total number of pencils is 48, so we can set up the equation: x + 2x + 2x + 5 = 48. Simplifying this equation, we get 5x + 5 = 48. Subtracting 5 from both sides, we get 5x = 43. Dividing both sides by 5, we get x = 8.6. Since we can't have a fraction of a pencil, we round down to the nearest whole number. Therefore, Mark has 8 pencils.
A group of friends went to a movie theater and bought a total of 35 tickets. Sarah bought 4 more tickets than John, and John bought twice as many tickets as Alex. How many tickets did Alex buy?

Let's call the number of tickets Alex bought "x". Then, John bought "2x" tickets and Sarah bought "2x+4" tickets. We know that the total number of tickets is 35, so we can set up the equation: x + 2x + 2x + 4 = 35. Simplifying this equation, we get 5x + 4 = 35. Subtracting 4 from both sides, we get 5x = 31. Dividing both sides by 5, we get x = 6.2. Since we can't have a fraction of a ticket, we round down to the nearest whole number. Therefore, Alex bought 6 tickets.
A group of students have a total of 60 books. Tom has 8 more books than Jane, and Jane has three times as many books as Mark. How many books does Mark have?

Let's call the number of books Mark has "x". Then, Jane has "3x" books and Tom has "3x+8" books. We know that the total number of books is 60, so we can set up the equation: x + 3x + 3x + 8 = 60. Simplifying this equation, we get 7x + 8 = 60. Subtracting 8 from both sides, we get 7x = 52. Dividing both sides by 7, we get x = 7.428. Since we can't have a fraction of a book, we round down to the nearest whole number. Therefore, Mark has 7 books.

On Halloween, Jack went trick-or-treating and collected a total of 36 candies. He had 4 more chocolate candies than lollipops, twice as many gummy bears as chocolate candies, and one-third as many sour candies as gummy bears. How many of each type of candy did Jack collect?

Let's start by assigning variables to each type of candy. Let c be the number of chocolate candies, l be the number of lollipops, g be the number of gummy bears, and s be the number of sour candies. We know that c = l + 4, g = 2c, and s = (1/3)g. We also know that the total number of candies is 36, so we can write an equation: c + l + g + s = 36. Substituting the expressions for c, g, and s in terms of l, we get (l+4) + l + 2(l+4) + (1/3)(2(l+4)) = 36. Solving for l, we get l = 6. Then, we can find the other variables: c = 10, g = 20, and s = 6.

If it takes 4 horses traveling at the same speed a total of 24 hours to travel across a field, how many hours will it take six cows, each traveling at half the speed of a horse, to do so?

Let's assume that the distance across the field is d. Then, the speed of each horse is d/24 and the speed of each cow is (1/2)(d/24) = d/48. The total distance traveled by the horses is 4d, and the total distance traveled by the cows is 6d. Since distance = speed x time, we can set up the equation 4d = (d/48)t, where t is the time it takes for the cows to cross the field. Solving for t, we get t = 192 hours.

A school is hosting a talent show. The show will be 3 hours long. Each group will have 3 minutes to get on stage, 5 minutes to perform, and then 2 minutes to exit the stage. If there will be a 15-minute intermission, how many groups can perform in the talent show?

There are 60 minutes in an hour, so the talent show will be 3 x 60 = 180 minutes long. The time each group will take on stage is 3 + 5 + 2 = 10 minutes. The total time for each group including the time to get on and off stage is 10 x 2 = 20 minutes. The time for the intermission is 15 minutes. Therefore, the total time for each group including the intermission is 20 + 15 = 35 minutes. The number of groups that can perform in the talent show is 180 / 35 = 5.

A theater is hosting a play. The play will be 2.5 hours long. Each group will have 4 minutes to get on stage, 8 minutes to perform, and then 3 minutes to exit the stage. If there will be a 20-minute intermission, how many groups can perform in the play?

There are 60 minutes in an hour, so the play will be 2.5 x 60 = 150 minutes long. The time each group will take on stage is 4 + 8 + 3 = 15 minutes. Mr. Johnson has three farms, Farm A, Farm B, and Farm C. He has 70 cows in Farm A, 50 cows in Farm B, and 30 cows in Farm C. He sold 15 cows from Farm A and three times as many cows from Farm B. How many cows are left in the three farms altogether?

Mr. Johnson sold 15 cows from Farm A, so he has 70 - 15 = 55 cows left in Farm A. He sold three times as many cows from Farm B, which is 3 x 50 = 150 cows. So, he has 50 - 150 = -100 cows left in Farm B. This means he has no cows left in Farm B. He still has 30 cows in Farm C. Therefore, he has 55 + 30 = 85 cows left in the two farms altogether.

Mr. Brown sold 15 pigs from Farm X, so he has 80 - 15 = 65 pigs left in Farm X. He sold one-third as many pigs from Farm Y, which is 1/3 x 60 = 20 pigs. So, he has 60 - 20 = 40 pigs left in Farm Y. He still has 40 pigs in Farm Z. Therefore, he has 65 + 40 + 40 = 145 pigs left in the three farms altogether.

Mrs. Garcia has two farms, Farm A and Farm B. She has 50 sheep in Farm A and 30 sheep in Farm B. She sold 10 sheep from Farm A and three-fourths as many sheep from Farm B. How many sheep are left in the two farms altogether?

Mrs. Garcia sold 10 sheep from Farm A, so she has 50 - 10 = 40 sheep left in Farm A. She sold three-fourths as many sheep from Farm B, which is 3/4 x 30 = 22.5 sheep. Since she cannot sell half a sheep, she sold 22 sheep from Farm B. So, she has 30 - 22 = 8 sheep left in Farm B. Therefore, she has 40 + 8 = 48 sheep left in the two farms altogether.

Mr. Kim has three farms, Farm P, Farm Q, and Farm R. He has 90 ducks in Farm P, 70 ducks in Farm Q, and 50 ducks in Farm R. He sold 20 ducks from Farm P, twice as many ducks from Farm Q, and half as many ducks from Farm R. How many ducks are left in the three farms altogether?

Mr. Kim sold 20 ducks from Farm P, so he has 90 - 20 = 70 ducks left in Farm P. He sold twice as many ducks from Farm Q, which is 2 x 70 = 140 ducks. So, he has 70 - 140 = -70 ducks left in Farm Q. This means he has no ducks left in Farm Q. He sold half as many ducks from Farm R, which is 1/2 x 50 = 25 ducks. So, he has 50 - 25 = 25 ducks left in Farm R. Therefore, he has 70 + 25 = 95 ducks left in the two farms altogether.
James buys 2 pairs of shoes a month. He spends $2640 on shoes each year. How much does he pay on average for each pair of shoes?

To find the average cost per pair of shoes, we need to divide the total amount spent on shoes by the total number of pairs of shoes bought in a year. James buys 2 pairs of shoes per month, so he buys 2 x 12 = 24 pairs of shoes in a year. Therefore, the average cost per pair of shoes is $2640 ÷ 24 = $110.
Sarah buys 3 dresses a month. She spends $1800 on dresses each year. How much does she pay on average for each dress?

To find the average cost per dress, we need to divide the total amount spent on dresses by the total number of dresses bought in a year. Sarah buys 3 dresses per month, so she buys 3 x 12 = 36 dresses in a year. Therefore, the average cost per dress is $1800 ÷ 36 = $50.
John buys 4 books a month. He spends $960 on books each year. How much does he pay on average for each book?

To find the average cost per book, we need to divide the total amount spent on books by the total number of books bought in a year. John buys 4 books per month, so he buys 4 x 12 = 48 books in a year. Therefore, the average cost per book is $960 ÷ 48 = $20.

A basket of green food costs $30 and a basket of red food costs $20. If you buy 2 baskets of green food and 3 baskets of red food, how much will you have to pay in total if you get $3 off for each basket of green food?

The cost of 2 baskets of green food is 2 x $30 = $60. The cost of 3 baskets of red food is 3 x $20 = $60. The total cost before discount is $120. The discount for each basket of green food is $3, so the total discount for 2 baskets of green food is 2 x $3 = $6. The final cost is $120 - $6 = $114.
